postsData.name:
Mahmoud Owies
Mahmoud Owies
postsData.content:
You don't need to be the best to be confident...

You don't need to be the best to be worthy...

And you definitely don't need to be the best to try...

I've spent most of my life thinking the exact opposite...If I'm not the best at "A" then I don't deserve to get "B".

Why would I win? Why would I be the lucky one?

They're better so it makes sense they'll be the winners...

Essentially, I thought that there's some sort of ranking, and because I'm not the absolute best at everything in life, I don't deserve or I'm not worthy enough to get what I want...

The "aim low because that's what you deserve" mentality....

But no surprise here, I was wrong...Very wrong...

And the thing that made me most wrong is my definition of confidence...

I thought...That confidence means you're better than the rest...

That a confident person is the person who believes they're god's gift to earth and they're the ultimate answer to every problem...

So...Whenever I realized that I'm not the best at something, I immediately shrank and I felt it in my core...I'm not the best...I should hide...Run away...Burry myself...Never try...I don't deserve to...

But confidence is not thinking you're the absolute best at everything...It's not thinking that you're better than others...It's believing that you can figure it out...You can handle whatever life throws at you...Being confident is going for what you want (despite not being the best at the moment) and believing that you can get it...You will get it...You'll figure out a way...You are the master of your own destiny.

How about you? What's your definition of confidence?

P.S. This is the first part (yes, It was a very long post). Stay tuned for the sequel.

comments.commentText: Mahmoud Owies this boy is on fire . Confidence is about joining the broken pieces and screaming out loud : Come what may, I will rise up like the Pheonix.

postsData.commentAdded: What a powerful reflection! Confidence truly comes from within and the belief in our ability to grow. Excited for part two! üåü

Dr. Miro Bada
postsData.content:
10 Things NOT To Say at Work,
And What To SAY Instead.

I've seen careers derailed in seconds.

The cause?
A few poorly chosen words.

One simple phrase can:
‚Ü≥ Build trust or destroy it
‚Ü≥ Get you promoted or fired
‚Ü≥ Solve problems or create many more

The wrong words WILL destroy your career. 
Don't let it happen to you.

Use this guide to avoid the pitfalls,
And build a positive reputation:

1.  Don't say: "That's not my job"
 Why: Shows inflexibility. Labels you as unhelpful.
 Say: "I can help you find the right person for this"

2.  Don't say: "I don't get paid enough for this"
 Why: Unprofessional. Makes you look entitled.
 Say: "Can we discuss my role scope?"

3.  Don't say: "Who messed this up?"
 Why: Creates blame culture. Breeds toxicity.
 Say: "How can we prevent this going forward?"

4.  Don't say: "I can't work with them"
 Why: Shows poor adaptability. Makes you look difficult.
 Say: "How can we collaborate better?"

5.  Don't say: "Not my problem"
 Why: Shows poor ownership. Labels you as difficult.
 Say: "How can I support the solution?"

6.  Don't say: "It's not fair"
 Why: Sounds immature. Shows poor understanding.
 Say: "Help me understand the reasoning"

7.  Don't say: "That's above my pay grade"
 Why: Shows lack of initiative. Seems dismissive.
 Say: "Let me check with the appropriate team"

8.  Don't say: "That's impossible"
 Why: Shows defeat. Lacks a problem-solving mindset.
 Say: "Let's identify the main challenges"

9.  Don't say: "I thought someone else would do it"
 Why: Shows poor accountability. Shifts blame.
 Say: "I should have confirmed the ownership"

10.  Don't say: "That's how we've always done it"
 Why: Shows resistance to change. Blocks innovation.
 Say: "Let's evaluate if this still works best"

Remember:
It's not just what you say, but how you say it.

Every word shapes your reputation.
Every response defines your future.

P.S. Any you'd add?

The Transience of Pain and the Permanence of Perseverance:

Lance Armstrong's words remind us of the transient nature of pain and the lasting impact of our choices when facing it. Pain, in all its forms, is part of the human experience - a fleeting visitor that prompts growth, empathy, and, often, transformation.

As we navigate through the discomforts that life sometimes presents, it's worth remembering that pain is not an endless night but a passing storm, and with time, it gives way to clearer skies.

Have you ever pushed through a difficult period only to emerge stronger? Share your testament to perseverance or inspire others to persist with a message of hope. Let's honor the resilience that exists in all of us.

postsData.content:
The Crypto Jungle is Burning ‚Äì And Most Won‚Äôt Escape

Imagine waking up to check your Coinbase account‚Äîonly to find everything gone. $65 million drained from users through phishing attacks so sophisticated, even seasoned traders got tricked in the last 60-days and $350M this past year. 

Now zoom out. This isn‚Äôt just Coinbase. This week, hackers tore through DeFi protocols, centralized exchanges, and individual wallets, stealing millions through every possible attack vector. No one is safe.
 Ionic Money? Exploited for $7M.
 Xeggex Exchange? Multi-million dollar hot wallet drain.
 Telegram support scams? Exploding, with users handing over their private keys without hesitation.
 DeFi rug pulls? Still happening, still draining portfolios overnight.

The Worst Part? It‚Äôs not one type of attack‚Äîit‚Äôs everything, everywhere, all at once.

The Game Has Changed
Scammers aren‚Äôt just running Discord bots and Telegram phishing campaigns anymore. They‚Äôre using AI, deepfake voices, and real-time social engineering to break into accounts and wallets.

Some ‚Äúinsider‚Äù leaks point to centralized exchange API keys being compromised, leading to sudden balance wipes. Elsewhere, DeFi devs are inserting hidden backdoors into smart contracts‚Äîeven after audits.

And here‚Äôs the kicker: the biggest hacks haven‚Äôt even been discovered yet.
Survival Requires a Mindset Shift

Most people in Web3 think a good wallet and 2FA will keep them safe. That‚Äôs outdated thinking. The real threats today are:
 AI-powered phishing campaigns that mimic real support teams.
 Compromised developer accounts pushing poisoned code.
 Backdoored smart contracts designed to fail months after launch.

If you‚Äôre in crypto, you‚Äôre in a war zone. Your money is constantly under attack.

What Happens Next?
Exchanges will fall. Hackers are already inside some of them.
Rug pulls will evolve. New projects will launch with pre-planned exploits.
Security tools will fail. Because no one‚Äôs thinking far enough ahead.
The reality? Web3 isn‚Äôt ready for what‚Äôs coming next. But the ones who adapt‚Äîwho stay ahead of the threats‚Äîwill be the ones who survive.

Are you ready? 
 What‚Äôs the biggest risk you‚Äôre seeing in the wild? Drop a comment.
 Repost to warn others.

ùóñùó¶ ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóøùòÄ: You're driving renewals and expansion, but does your Executive Team see you as a Revenue Leader?

You may be ùê¨ùê≠ùêÆùêúùê§ ùê¢ùêß ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêÇ-ùêíùêÆùê¢ùê≠ùêû ùêàùê¶ùê©ùêöùêúùê≠ ùêÜùêöùê©.

This is the gap between ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùêöùêúùê≠ ùê≤ùê®ùêÆ ùê§ùêßùê®ùê∞ ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùê≠ùêûùêöùê¶ ùê¢ùê¨ ùê¶ùêöùê§ùê¢ùêßùê† and ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê∞ùêöùê≤ ùê•ùêûùêöùêùùêûùê´ùê¨ùê°ùê¢ùê© ùê©ùêûùê´ùêúùêûùê¢ùêØùêûùê¨ ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêúùê®ùêßùê≠ùê´ùê¢ùêõùêÆùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß.

And it happens when CS leaders focus solely on ùêúùêÆùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêûùê´ ùê®ùêÆùê≠ùêúùê®ùê¶ùêûùê¨ without tying them to ùêõùêÆùê¨ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨ùê¨ ùê®ùêÆùê≠ùêúùê®ùê¶ùêûùê¨.

 ùêòùê®ùêÆ ùêùùê´ùê¢ùêØùêû ùê´ùêûùê≠ùêûùêßùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß‚Äîbut does the CFO see CS as a revenue protector?
 ùêòùê®ùêÆ ùêùùê´ùê¢ùêØùêû ùêûùê±ùê©ùêöùêßùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêß‚Äîbut does the CRO see CS as a revenue enabler?
 ùêòùê®ùêÆ ùêùùê´ùê¢ùêØùêû ùêúùêÆùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêûùê´ ùê°ùêûùêöùê•ùê≠ùê°‚Äîbut does the CEO see CS as critical to financial health?

If not, maybe you‚Äôre still operating ùêöùê¨ ùêö ùê¨ùê≠ùêöùêßùêùùêöùê•ùê®ùêßùêû ùêüùêÆùêßùêúùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß, rather than being embedded in the company‚Äôs ùêúùê®ùê´ùêû ùêüùê¢ùêßùêöùêßùêúùê¢ùêöùê• ùêöùêßùêù ùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêöùê≠ùêûùê†ùê¢ùêú ùê†ùê®ùêöùê•ùê¨.


ùêìùê°ùêû ùêíùê°ùê¢ùêüùê≠: ùêÖùê´ùê®ùê¶ ùêÇùêí ùêìùêûùêöùê¶-ùêÖùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠ ùê≠ùê® ùêÅùêÆùê¨ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨ùê¨-ùêÖùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠


ùòàùò≥ùò¶ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ ùò±ùò≥ùò™ùò∞ùò≥ùò™ùòµùò™ùòªùò™ùòØùò® ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ùò≥ ùòµùò¶ùò¢ùòÆ‚Äôùò¥ ùò¥ùò∂ùò§ùò§ùò¶ùò¥ùò¥ ùò∞ùò∑ùò¶ùò≥ ùò¶ùòπùò¶ùò§ùò∂ùòµùò™ùò∑ùò¶ ùò¢ùò≠ùò™ùò®ùòØùòÆùò¶ùòØùòµ?

ùòûùò©ùò¢ùòµ ùò•ùò∞ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ ùò¥ùò¶ùò¶ ùò¢ùò¥ ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂ùò≥ ùò±ùò≥ùò™ùòÆùò¢ùò≥ùò∫ ùò≥ùò¶ùò¥ùò±ùò∞ùòØùò¥ùò™ùò£ùò™ùò≠ùò™ùòµùò∫?
 Leading the CS function or
 Operating as part of the executive leadership team


This is where the "ùêÖùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠ ùêìùêûùêöùê¶" (ùòóùò¢ùòµùò≥ùò™ùò§ùò¨ ùòìùò¶ùòØùò§ùò™ùò∞ùòØùò™ ùò§ùò∞ùòØùò§ùò¶ùò±ùòµ) becomes critical.


Instead of ùêöùêùùêØùê®ùêúùêöùê≠ùê¢ùêßùê† ùêüùê®ùê´ ùêÇùêí ùêüùê´ùê®ùê¶ ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùê®ùêÆùê≠ùê¨ùê¢ùêùùêû, you ùêûùê¶ùêõùêûùêù ùêÇùêí ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùêßùê§ùê¢ùêßùê† ùê¢ùêßùê¨ùê¢ùêùùêû executive strategy.

Ô∏è ùêòùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêüùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠ ùê≠ùêûùêöùê¶ is not your CS team‚Äîit's ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêüùêûùê•ùê•ùê®ùê∞ ùêûùê±ùêûùêúùêÆùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêûùê¨.

Ô∏è ùêòùê®ùêÆùê´ ùê•ùêöùêßùê†ùêÆùêöùê†ùêû ùê¨ùê°ùê¢ùêüùê≠ùê¨ from CS metrics ùê≠ùê® ùêüùê¢ùêßùêöùêßùêúùê¢ùêöùê• ùê©ùêûùê´ùêüùê®ùê´ùê¶ùêöùêßùêúùêû.

Ô∏è ùêòùê®ùêÆùê´ ùê¶ùêûùêûùê≠ùê¢ùêßùê†ùê¨ ùê¨ùê°ùê¢ùêüùê≠ from fighting for budget ùê≠ùê® ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêØùê¢ùêßùê† ùê´ùêûùêØùêûùêßùêÆùêû ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùêöùêúùê≠.


ùêáùê®ùê∞ ùê≠ùê® ùêÇùê•ùê®ùê¨ùêû ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêÜùêöùê©:

1Ô∏è‚É£ ùêäùêßùê®ùê∞ ùêòùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêëùêûùêØùêûùêßùêÆùêû ùêàùê¶ùê©ùêöùêúùê≠ ‚Äì Revenue - Cost = Margin and Profitability

2Ô∏è‚É£ ùêÄùê•ùê¢ùê†ùêß ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêÑùê±ùêûùêúùêÆùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêû ùêìùêûùêöùê¶ ùêÖùê¢ùê´ùê¨ùê≠ ‚Äì Get aligned with Finance, Sales, Marketing, Product & Engineering on business-wide objectives.

3Ô∏è‚É£ ùêÇùê®ùê¶ùê¶ùêÆùêßùê¢ùêúùêöùê≠ùêû ùê¢ùêß ùêÅùêÆùê¨ùê¢ùêßùêûùê¨ùê¨ ùêìùêûùê´ùê¶ùê¨ ‚Äì How do onboarding, adoption, renewals and expansion impact your business‚Äô bottom line?


ùë®ùíìùíÜ ùíÄùíêùíñ ùëπùíÜùíÇùíÖùíö ùíïùíê ùë©ùíÜ ùë∫ùíÜùíÜùíè ùíÇùíî ùíÇ ùëπùíÜùíóùíÜùíèùíñùíÜ ùë≥ùíÜùíÇùíÖùíÜùíì?


CS is at a crossroads.

Leaders who embrace a first-team business mindset will step into executive influence.

Those who don‚Äôt will continue to struggle for recognition, budget, and career growth.

Where do you stand? Drop a comment below‚Äîlet‚Äôs discuss.

How does a failed baseball career turn into a CEO success story?

Damon Lembi was supposed to be a pro baseball player.
He had the talent, the drive, the dream.
But then - BOOM.
A curveball he never saw coming.
Career over. Plan shattered. Future unknown.

Most people would‚Äôve crumbled. He didn‚Äôt.

Instead, he did what every great leader does: he pivoted, adapted, and built something even bigger.

For nearly three decades,has led Learnit, a global training company that has helped 1.8 million professionals upskill and stay ahead in their careers.

Best-selling author, CEO, podcast host - Damon spent decades proving one thing - the ability to learn, grow, and reinvent yourself is the ultimate competitive advantage.

Thinking of leaving your corporate job to start your own thing?
Here is Damon's advice:

 Own it. With freedom comes full responsibility - every decision, every failure, every success falls on you.
 It‚Äôs a lot of work. There‚Äôs no straight path. Get ready!
 Do what excites you. Your business doesn‚Äôt need to disrupt an industry - it just needs to be something you deeply care about that's monetisable.

In this episode, Damon also shares:
-> The setbacks that became his biggest advantage
-> What pro sports taught him about leadership
-> The mindset shift that separates the best from the rest

 If you‚Äôre serious about change, don‚Äôt miss this. Hit the link and watch it now:

Subscribe to @‚ÄúChange is Possible - Your Career Transformation Guide" podcast and get unfiltered conversations with leaders who‚Äôve turned failure into success.

What‚Äôs one moment in your life that felt like a setback but turned out to be a gift?

comments.commentText:
So true! Ani

Setbacks often shape the strongest leaders. 

The ability to pivot and reinvent ourselves is the real unfair advantage in life.

50 Days of DSA with Java ‚Äì Day 1 
Kicking off my 50-day DSA journey with Selection Sort and Bubble Sort!  Sorting is a fundamental concept in Data Structures & Algorithms, and these two methods lay the foundation for understanding more advanced sorting techniques.
 Selection Sort ‚Äì Finds the smallest element and swaps it with the first unsorted element, repeating until sorted.
 Bubble Sort ‚Äì Repeatedly swaps adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order, pushing the largest elements to the end.
 Implemented both algorithms in Java with step-by-step explanations and code.
Check it out and let me know your thoughts!
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting start to your DSA journey! Sorting algorithms are crucial for deeper understanding. Looking forward to your upcoming posts! üöÄ

postsData.content:
ùóïùó≤ùòÜùóºùóªùó± ùóüùóüùó†ùòÄ: ùóîùóøùó≤ ùó™ùó≤ ùó¶ùòÅùòÇùó∞ùó∏ ùó∂ùóª ùóÆ ùóüùóºùó∞ùóÆùóπ ùó†ùóÆùòÖùó∂ùó∫ùòÇùó∫?

At the AI Action Summit, Yann LeCun made a bold claim:
‚Äúùòêùòß ùò∫ùò∞ùò∂‚Äôùò≥ùò¶ ùò™ùòØùòµùò¶ùò≥ùò¶ùò¥ùòµùò¶ùò• ùò™ùòØ ùò©ùò∂ùòÆùò¢ùòØ-ùò≠ùò¶ùò∑ùò¶ùò≠ ùòàùòê, ùò•ùò∞ùòØ‚Äôùòµ ùò∏ùò∞ùò≥ùò¨ ùò∞ùòØ ùòìùòìùòîùò¥.‚Äù

It‚Äôs easy to take this as an outright dismissal of large language models, but I see it differently. LLMs have given us an incredible leap forward in AI, but they‚Äôre also exposing the limits of scaling alone. Are we optimizing within a local maximum instead of pushing toward something fundamentally different?

ùóßùóµùó≤ ùóøùó≤ùóÆùóπ ùóæùòÇùó≤ùòÄùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùó∂ùòÄùóª‚ÄôùòÅ ùóüùóüùó†ùòÄ ùòÉùòÄ. ùóªùóº ùóüùóüùó†ùòÄ‚Äîùó∂ùòÅ‚ÄôùòÄ ùòÑùóµùóÆùòÅ ùó∞ùóºùó∫ùó≤ùòÄ ùóªùó≤ùòÖùòÅ.

 ùó™ùó≤‚ÄôùòÉùó≤ ùóºùòÉùó≤ùóø-ùó∂ùóªùó±ùó≤ùòÖùó≤ùó± ùóºùóª ùó±ùóÆùòÅùóÆ ùóÆùóªùó± ùóΩùóÆùóøùóÆùó∫ùó≤ùòÅùó≤ùóøùòÄ‚Äîbut intelligence isn‚Äôt just statistical pattern matching.
 ùó™ùó≤ ùóπùóÆùó∞ùó∏ ùóΩùó≤ùóøùòÄùó∂ùòÄùòÅùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùó∫ùó≤ùó∫ùóºùóøùòÜ ùóÆùóªùó± ùóøùó≤ùóÆùóπ-ùòÑùóºùóøùóπùó± ùó¥ùóøùóºùòÇùóªùó±ùó∂ùóªùó¥‚Äîleading to brittle reasoning.
 ùó¶ùó∞ùóÆùóπùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóπùóÆùòÑùòÄ ùòÑùóºùóøùó∏‚ÄîùòÇùóªùòÅùó∂ùóπ ùòÅùóµùó≤ùòÜ ùó±ùóºùóª‚ÄôùòÅ‚Äîand diminishing returns are setting in.

ùóòùóªùòÅùó≤ùóø ùóúùóªùó±ùòÇùòÄùòÅùóøùó∂ùóÆùóπ ùóîùóú: ùó™ùóµùòÜ ùóßùóµùó∂ùòÄ ùó†ùóÆùòÅùòÅùó≤ùóøùòÄ ùóïùó≤ùòÜùóºùóªùó± ùóñùóµùóÆùòÅùóØùóºùòÅùòÄ

LLMs may be impressive for text generation, but ùó∂ùóªùó±ùòÇùòÄùòÅùóøùó∂ùóÆùóπ ùóîùóú ùó±ùó≤ùó∫ùóÆùóªùó±ùòÄ ùó∫ùóºùóøùó≤ ùòÅùóµùóÆùóª ùóπùóÆùóªùó¥ùòÇùóÆùó¥ùó≤ ùó∫ùóºùó±ùó≤ùóπùòÄ. postsData.content:
Everyone says they‚Äôre ‚Äúdata-driven.‚Äù

But most companies aren‚Äôt.

Here‚Äôs 7 signs your company is *actually* data-driven:

Being data-driven isn‚Äôt about collecting reports.

It‚Äôs about how your company thinks, decides, and operates.

If data isn‚Äôt influencing real behavior, it‚Äôs just a buzzword.

Here are 7 signs your company actually runs on data:

1. Someone Owns Data Quality

- Data isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúavailable‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs trusted
- There‚Äôs a clear owner ensuring clean, accurate data

Pro-Tip: Assign a dedicated leader to data governance. If no one is responsible, everyone is guessing.

2. New Projects Start With a Data Plan

- Data collection is considered before the first line of code
- Performance tracking is built into launches from day one

Pro-Tip: Make data planning mandatory in project kickoffs. If it‚Äôs an afterthought, you‚Äôll always be playing catch-up.

3. Opinions Come With Numbers

- People naturally back up their ideas with data
- The phrase ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the data?‚Äù is part of daily discussions

Pro-Tip: Normalize data-backed decision-making. If gut feelings drive key choices, you‚Äôre not data-driven.

4. Bad Numbers Aren‚Äôt Hidden

- Underperformance isn‚Äôt ignored‚Äîit‚Äôs analyzed
- Data is used to improve, not to blame

Pro-Tip: Encourage transparency. If teams fear sharing bad results, they‚Äôll manipulate data instead of fixing problems.

5. Everyone Can Access Relevant Data

- Teams don‚Äôt need to ‚Äúask IT‚Äù for key reports
- Employees can quickly pull insights related to their work

Pro-Tip: Invest in self-service analytics. If data is locked away, it‚Äôs useless.

6. Every Goal Has a Measurable Target

- Objectives come with clear KPIs, not vague aspirations
- Success is measured, not assumed

Pro-Tip: Tie every strategic goal to a specific metric. If you can‚Äôt measure it, you won‚Äôt improve it.

7. Data Training Is a Priority

- Employees know how to interpret and use data
- Data literacy is seen as a core skill, not an ‚Äúextra‚Äù

Pro-Tip: Provide ongoing data education. If only the analysts understand data, your company isn‚Äôt truly data-driven.

Data-driven isn‚Äôt a claim. It‚Äôs a culture.

And if your company isn‚Äôt there yet‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs time to make a change.


Enjoy this?

Followfor tips on GenAI adoption, data engineering, and leadership.

comments.commentText: Everybody can get access to data these days. It's how you use that data and let it drive your decisions that makes a difference.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing a data-driven culture is essential for making informed decisions and fostering innovation. Time to level up! üöÄ

postsData.content:
Organization = Freedom (Yes, Really!) 

I used to think organization was about being rigid, controlling every detail, and making color-coded spreadsheets that looked nice but never got used (sound familiar?).

But then I learned a hard truth:  The more organized you are, the more people you can serve.**

It hit me when I found myself juggling a million things, feeling like I was "busy," but not actually moving forward. So I asked myself:

 If I could only get one thing done today, what would it be?

That simple question changed everything.

 It forced me to focus.
 It cut out distractions.
 It made my actions matter.

And guess what? The more I prioritized the right things, the more impact I had.

Look, we‚Äôre all human. We forget things. We have days where we stare at our to-do list and think, "Nope. Not today." But when we have structure‚Äîjust enough to keep us moving but not enough to make us feel trapped‚Äîit creates freedom.

 Freedom to serve more people.
 Freedom to scale our business.
 Freedom to actually enjoy the process.

So today, instead of trying to do everything, ask yourself:

 What‚Äôs the one thing that absolutely has to get done?

Then go do it.

What‚Äôs your One Thing today?

I‚Äôd love to hear it!

comments.commentText: Great insight, Clifford Starks... Focus > Impact!

postsData.commentAdded: Great reminder! Focusing on one priority can truly transform our productivity and impact. My One Thing today is reconnecting with a mentor. What about yours?

Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
postsData.content:
What‚Äôs the Secret to Building a High-Performing, Highly Engaged Team?

 Why Do Some Teams Thrive‚Ä¶ and Others Struggle
 What‚Äôs the Leadership Shift That Transforms Culture and Performance

Over the last thirty years, I've worked with exceptional clinic owners and leaders in healthcare and private medical self-care.

And I‚Äôve noticed something fascinating.

Some teams are engaged, collaborative, and constantly improving.

Others? Disengaged, cautious, and resistant to change.

So, what makes the difference?

I can tell‚Äîalmost immediately‚Äîwhen a practice has a high-performing team:

 Staff show up energised and full of ideas
 There‚Äôs a genuine sense of teamwork and shared purpose
 Conversations focus on better patient outcomes
 Leaders ask questions, listen, and encourage

And then, there are the teams where something feels‚Ä¶ off.

 Staff seem on edge or unusually quiet
 Leaders do most of the talking (or worse‚Äîdirecting)
 There‚Äôs a lack of collaboration or ownership
 High staff turnover is common

So, what‚Äôs the real secret to transforming these struggling teams?

Great Leaders Aren‚Äôt Born‚ÄîThey‚Äôre Developed
Many managers step into leadership without structured training. I was one of them.

Early in my career, I was promoted into management with little guidance. I struggled. It wasn‚Äôt until I asked for help, enroled in coaching, and committed to learning leadership skills that everything changed.

Within 12 months, I went from failing manager to leading an award-winning, high-performing team.

 Every leader has blind spots (it‚Äôs part of being human)
 Self-awareness is the key to unlocking leadership potential
 With the right training, culture and performance transform

The Secret? Psychological Safety 

If there‚Äôs one defining characteristic of high-performing teams, it‚Äôs this:

 Team members feel comfortable (safe) sharing their ideas and asking questions. They also take calculated risks‚Äîwithout fear of embarrassment or punishment.

This is psychological safety, and it‚Äôs the foundation of collaboration, innovation, and strong leadership.

When leaders create a safe, open environment, teams become:
Ô∏è More engaged
Ô∏è More Innovative
Ô∏è More committed to a shared purpose

But when people fear speaking up, performance plummets, stress rises, and turnover skyrockets.

How to Build Psychological Safety
 Start with Clarity ‚Äì Define your team‚Äôs purpose and values.

 Listen More, Talk Less ‚Äì Great leaders ask more questions than they answer.
 Encourage Ideas ‚Äì Every voice matters. Create space for innovation.
 Build Trust ‚Äì Be transparent, show empathy, and recognize contributions.

If your culture isn‚Äôt producing the results you need‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs talk.

Everyone has untapped potential.

If you feel your team could benefit from a more collaborative, empowered, and engaged culture, let‚Äôs connect.

 Drop me a message or comment below‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts!
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Psychological safety is crucial for team success. A culture of openness truly drives innovation and engagement. Lets connect!

AI tools that elevate productivity: How I use ChatGPT to create LinkedIn posts 

Many business owners hesitate to use AI, thinking it replaces creativity. But here‚Äôs the truth: AI enhances it.

Ô∏èStep 1: Train ChatGPT to understand your business

Before generating content, I ensure ChatGPT knows:
‚ÜíMy audience
‚ÜíTheir pain points (scaling, efficiency, AI adoption fears)
‚ÜíMy brand‚Äôs voice & expertise

How? I train it with:
‚Üí My LinkedIn engagement data to analyse what resonates
‚Üí My company website to align messaging
‚Üí A simple prompt: "Act as a LinkedIn brand-building expert. Ask me questions to define my audience and key pain points."

Ô∏èStep 2: Follow a high-impact post structure

After testing formats, this one delivers consistently:
‚ÜíHook: Start with a bold statement that grabs attention.
‚ÜíProblem: Address a key challenge your audience faces.
‚ÜíInsights: Provide clear, actionable solutions.
‚ÜíCTA: Prompt engagement or direct outreach.

Ô∏è Step 3: Analyze & refine with AI

Your job doesn‚Äôt end after posting. AI helps track & optimize:
‚ÜíWhich posts get the most engagement?
‚ÜíWhen is my audience most active?
‚ÜíWhat topics perform best?

Try prompts like:
‚ÄúAnalyze this LinkedIn post‚Äôs performance and suggest improvements.‚Äù
‚ÄúRewrite my next post to match my highest-performing content.‚Äù

AI is a tool, but strategy is key.
The best results come from leveraging AI while adding your unique expertise.

postsData.content:
Google Drops AI Weapons Ban: Ethics vs Market Reality

Google just dropped their AI weapons/surveillance restriction from their principles.

Let's be real - this isn't shocking. A tech giant adjusts ethics to match market realities. The surprise isn't that they dropped the pledge - it's that they managed to keep it for 5 years. In a free market, ethical self-restriction is a competitive disadvantage - your competitors won't hesitate while you play nice.

I'm against it, but let's be honest - this was inevitable.

Some context:
Ô∏è 2018: Google creates AI principles after Project Maven controversy
Ô∏è 2025: Principles shift from social impact focus to risk/benefit analysis

 The interesting part? Most big tech companies never made similar commitments. The standard was always more... flexible.

From my perspective, this highlights growing tension between:
üá™üá∫ European-style regulatory frameworks (EU AI Act, in force since 2 Feb 2025)
üá∫üá∏ Silicon Valley's "move fast" approach with Trump revoking executive order on AI risks
üá®üá≥ Rising geopolitical tech competition, exemplified by China's Trojan horse tactics with open sourcing DeepSeerk R1 model

The real question for us builders and engineers: How do you see this impacting global AI development standards? Particularly, with the EU AI Act coming into force this month.

Sources, including coverage of Trump's AI order revocation and DeepSeerk R1 analysis in comments ‚¨áÔ∏è

7 Brutal Truths of Growth 
(that nobody tells you):

Everyone wants growth.
Until they see what it actually costs.

Here's what they don't tell you in the success stories:

1. You‚Äôll want to quit just before the breakthrough
‚Ü≥ Your brain is wired to protect you from change
‚Ü≥ Maximum resistance signals transformation

2. Growth will cost you friends
‚Ü≥ Your success threatens their comfort zone
‚Ü≥ Their reaction is about their fears, not your potential

3. Growth feels like losing who you are
‚Ü≥ Your identity will fight to stay the same
‚Ü≥ Discomfort is your comfort zone expanding

4. It gets lonelier as you level up
‚Ü≥ The higher you climb, the fewer people get it
‚Ü≥ But the conversations become deeper, not wider

5. What got you here won‚Äôt get you there
‚Ü≥ Each level requires letting go of what worked before
‚Ü≥ Today's strength might block tomorrow‚Äôs growth

6. You‚Äôre building the plane while flying it
‚Ü≥ Perfect clarity comes through action, not planning
‚Ü≥ Every expert started as a confused beginner

7. Progress isn‚Äôt linear
‚Ü≥ What looks like failure is often recalibration
‚Ü≥ Your ‚Äúsetbacks‚Äù are setting you up for breakthroughs

The truth about growth?
It‚Äôs uncomfortable, messy, and often lonely.
But that‚Äôs how you know it‚Äôs working.

postsData.name:
Maarten Ottenhoff
Maarten Ottenhoff
postsData.content:
Check out our new preprint, where we decode goal-directed hand movements from brain-wide intracranial recordings. See a quick summary below, or find the full preprint here:.

In my work and in the Neural Interfacing Lab at,, we are interested in decoding behavior from brain-wide recordings, particularly movement in my case. We work together with participants implanted with sEEG electrodes allowing us to record neural activity throughout the brain.

In previous work, we described how movement can be decoded from brain-wide neural activity, across tasks and across participants. However, this was only decoding between move and rest, so naturally we wanted to know more about the neural content of these brain-wide dynamics.

To investigate, we recorded 3D hand movement trajectory while our participants played a custom made game where the goal was to move a pufferfish to a bubble to pop it. From the trajectories, we retrieved position, velocity, speed and acceleration. At the same time, we recorded neural activity from cortical and sub-cortical brain areas.

We extracted low frequency activity (< 5 HZ), mid frequency power (8 - 30 Hz) and high-frequency power (55 - 200 Hz), windowed the data (300ms length, 50ms shift), and used preferential subspace identification (PSID) to decode 12 kinematics.

We found that non-directional hand movement speed can be decoded using low, mid and high frequency information. Particularly, the low frequency activity reached substantial decoding performance (up to 0.76 + 0.03). Decoding directional components was a much bigger challenge for the decoder.

If we look at the electrode contact locations that were significantly correlated with hand movement speed, we observe that these contacts are located throughout the brain, including cortical and subcortical structures.

About the decoding of the directional kinematics. It turns out that if we change the reference frame from the sensor to the goal, that the decoder becomes able to decode position w.r.t. the target above chance! It suggests that the brain represents goal-directed movement in relationship to that goal.

Overall, the decoder reached the highest performance using low frequency activity. The phase information is important, as the performance was substantially lower when we used the power. This neural signal shares similarities with the local motor potential described in the motor cortex.

Our results provide a comprehensive overview of the decodable movement-related information in brain-wide neural activity, and strengthen our previous results that the whole brain may be involved in generating movement.

We are excited about this work and hope you enjoy reading it. As we always do in our lab, we share code and data publicly. Please find the code here:.

comments.commentText: As always, science is a team-effort. We are incredible thankful for all collaborators providing their input and expertise, the invaluable staff at Kempenhaeghe and our participants for providing their time and effort.
Also, please find my at @mottenhoff.bsky.social as well!

postsData.commentAdded: Exciting work! This research provides valuable insights into brain dynamics during movement‚Äîgreat to see the data shared publicly! #Neuroscience

This mistake almost ruined everything for me.

When I first started my journey, I thought I had to come up with something brand new to succeed.

A unique strategy. A never-before-seen concept.

Big mistake.

I wasted time trying to be original when I should‚Äôve been studying what was already working.

Trying to reinvent the wheel slowed me down, and nearly made me quit.

Once I shifted my mindset, everything changed. Success is not about being first. It‚Äôs about being better.

Apple didn‚Äôt invent smartphones.
They just made them better.

Facebook wasn‚Äôt the first social network.
They just built a better experience.

Google wasn‚Äôt the first search engine.
They just did it best.

So when my clients ask how to grow on YouTube, I tell them this:

 Pick a niche that already has winners. If others are making money in it, that‚Äôs proof it works.

 Study their strategies. Look at their top-performing content, their thumbnails, their titles - reverse-engineer their success.

 Refine and execute. Take what works, add your unique edge, improve the quality, and go all in.

This is how you win. Not by wasting time trying to be different, but by being better.
That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the game.

If you're trying to grow on YouTube (or any business), don‚Äôt waste time trying to be completely unique.

Model success, refine it with your own edge, and execute relentlessly.

Innovation is great.
But execution is what wins.
Every. Single. Time.

You don‚Äôt need to reinvent the wheel.
Just make it better.

Are you making the same mistake I did? Or are you ready to dominate? Let‚Äôs talk.

Jen Blandos
postsData.content:
Micromanagement doesn‚Äôt improve performance.

It drives your best people away.

It's not just shouting or threats - it's often subtle, unintentional behaviours that create uncertainty, anxiety, and disengagement.

Here are 8 common fear-based behaviours leaders might display - and how to fix them:

 1. Unclear expectations.
Your team feels like they‚Äôre guessing what success looks like, leaving them unsure and anxious.

 Set clear, measurable goals.
Define what success looks like for every project. Use regular check-ins to ensure alignment and clarity.

 2. Imposing unnecessary urgency.
Fake deadlines or piling on ‚Äúemergency‚Äù tasks might seem like driving results, but it breeds stress and burnout.

 Align urgency with priorities.
Explain why deadlines matter and connect them to business goals. Ensure the workload is realistic.

 3. Using vague or critical feedback.
Statements like ‚ÄúWe need to talk about your performance‚Äù without explanation leave employees fearful and defensive.

 Offer actionable feedback.
Use a constructive approach: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what‚Äôs working, here‚Äôs where improvement is needed, and here‚Äôs how I‚Äôll support you.‚Äù

 4. Micromanaging tasks.
Stepping in to ‚Äúfix‚Äù things or taking over sends the message that you don‚Äôt trust your team.

 Delegate and empower.
Give your team ownership of tasks and let them find solutions, even if it means learning through mistakes.

 5. Ignoring achievements.
Focusing only on mistakes and what‚Äôs not working demotivates your team over time.

 Celebrate wins regularly.
Recognise successes - big or small. Regular appreciation builds confidence and encourages better performance.

 6. Keeping your team in the dark.
When employees don‚Äôt have visibility into decisions or changes, it creates uncertainty and mistrust.

 Be transparent.
Communicate openly about decisions, changes, and challenges. Transparency builds trust and loyalty.

 7. Creating fear around job security.
Saying things like, ‚ÄúMany people would love to have your role,‚Äù fosters a toxic, competitive environment.

 Provide reassurance and growth paths.
Focus on development: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how we can work together to build your skills and grow your career.‚Äù

 8. Treating performance reviews as threats.
Using appraisals as punishment creates fear instead of driving improvement.

 Turn reviews into coaching opportunities.
Use performance reviews to discuss growth, strengths, and opportunities for the future‚Äînot as a disciplinary tool.

Fear doesn‚Äôt lead to excellence - trust does.

The best leaders create environments where their teams feel supported, safe, and empowered to innovate and grow.

What‚Äôs one leadership habit you‚Äôre improving right now?
 Repost to inspire more empowered workplaces.
 Follow me, Jen Blandos, for daily insights on leadership, business, and workplace wellbeing.

postsData.content:
I am managing 48 opportunities...and counting.

They are ALL active. What does that mean?

1. My Activity - 43 have outbound activity in the last 3 business days.

2. Their Activity - 38 have inbound activity in the last 5 business days.

3. Next Meetings - 22 have meetings in the next 5 business days.

4. Past Meetings - 35 held meetings in the last 5 business days.

5. Response Times - 17 hour average time to a reply.

6. Other - 12 were on vacation or at SKO last week or this week.


How do I stay on top of that many deals?

1. We use task queues in's CRM.

Sidenote:
Startups should not use Salesforce.
Hubspot is easier, less expensive, and more connected.

Task queues group tasks together.

I have a queue for each meeting in's sales process.

I have a basic task queue structure:
1. book - I need to book the meeting
2. prep - Meeting is booked and need to be ready for it
3. held/review - Meeting was held, next steps require some thought and/or purpose of the meeting wasn't accomplished


2. I create task queue views.

The views show me all deals with tasks in that queue.

So simple to run through a bunch of similar tasks.



3. Task execution flow.

Hubspot has a really cool screen dedicated to getting tasks done.

I only do followup tasks during certain time blocks of the week.

I go to the view of a queue and then start the tasks.

The UI of the execution flow helps me stay focused and mow 'em down.



4. Time blocking.

I have blocks for doing "office work" on Monday morning, Wed all day, Thurs morning, and Friday afternoon.

I always feel like I'm running around completely unfocused without time blocks.



Ô∏è Consider reposting to share how to stay on top of a lot of deals.

 Do you use tasks in your CRM? No...like actually use them?

postsData.content:
Musharakah in Action: How Banks Fuel Growth Through Ethical Partnerships
In our last post, we saw how Musharakah helped Ahmed and Khalid turn a simple bakery into a thriving business. But did you know that banks also use Musharakah to fund businesses while staying Shari‚Äôah-compliant?

Let‚Äôs explore the two key types of Musharakah‚ÄîShirkat-ul-Milk and Shirkat-ul-Aqd‚Äîand see how they shape financial partnerships.

1. Shirkat-ul-Milk: Ownership-Based Partnership
This type of Musharakah happens when two or more people jointly own an asset, either by choice or by circumstance.

 Example: Ayesha and Zaid inherit a commercial property. Instead of selling it, they rent it out and share the rental income. This is Shirkat-ul-Milk in action!
But Musharakah isn‚Äôt just about co-owning properties‚Äîit plays a vital role in banking too!

2. Shirkat-ul-Aqd: Business-Based Partnership
This is the true essence of Musharakah in Islamic banking, where partners pool capital, expertise, or resources for a business venture.

 Example: A startup needs funding, and an Islamic bank steps in, forming a Musharakah agreement. The bank provides capital, while the entrepreneurs contribute their skills. Profits are shared based on a pre-agreed ratio, and any loss is borne according to capital contribution.

How Banks Apply Musharakah

 Musharakah Financing: Instead of interest-based loans, banks invest in businesses, sharing profits and risks.

 Home Financing: The bank and the customer jointly purchase a house, with the customer gradually buying the bank‚Äôs share.

 Agricultural & SME Growth: Farmers and small businesses get direct investment rather than debt, fostering sustainable expansion.

Why It Matters

 Risk-sharing builds trust and fairness.
 Entrepreneurs get real support, not just loans.
 Banking becomes a tool for growth, not just profit.

What‚Äôs Next?

In our next post, we‚Äôll dive into Mudarabah, another fascinating Islamic finance model that fuels businesses while keeping risk and reward balanced. Stay tuned!

 Have you seen Musharakah in action? Would you prefer a profit-sharing model over traditional loans? Let‚Äôs discuss in the comments!

Your habits create your lifestyle.

If you want a different life..
You need different habits.

And habits don‚Äôt change on their own.
They change with intention.
Intention backed by action.

But action without clarity leads nowhere.
Clarity is what breaks the cycles that keep you stuck.

Because when you try to change‚Ä¶
Your mind fights back.
Old habits resist.
Comfort calls you back.

And here‚Äôs the truth:
Habits are the dots.
Individually, they seem small.
But when you connect them, they create momentum.

This is why you need a routine.
Your routine is simply connected habits.

Each habit feeds the next.
Each action reinforces the one before.

Alone, habits are scattered.
Together, they shape the structure of your life.
And when your habits align,
Your routine becomes unstoppable.

7 Steps to do this:

1. Own your routine
- Without a plan, you‚Äôll follow someone else‚Äôs.
- Design a structure that aligns with your goals.
- Build habits that move you forward, not hold you back.

2. Break the comfort cycle
- The easy path leads nowhere.
- Growth requires discomfort.
- Choose challenge over convenience.

3. Train your mind like a muscle
- Strength isn‚Äôt just physical, it‚Äôs mental.
- Master the art of focus and discipline.
- Your future depends on what you do daily.

4. Cut the noise
- Not everything deserves your attention.
- Filter out distractions that don‚Äôt serve you.
- Energy wasted on the wrong things is energy lost forever.

5. Build momentum through action
- Small wins create big shifts.
- Progress compounds over time.
- Start today, no matter how small the step.

6. Adapt and evolve
- Stagnation is the real failure.
- The best routines adjust as you grow.
- Stay flexible, but stay committed.

7. Define success on your terms
- Stop living by someone else‚Äôs script.
- Own your choices, your habits, your results.
- The life you want is built by the actions you take.

Most people drift.
They wake up and follow the same patterns.
Patterns they are given by others.

If you don‚Äôt take charge of your habits..
Someone else will.

If you don‚Äôt create your own routine..
You‚Äôll live by one designed for you.

Own them. Shape them. Align them.

Retrofitting an SQL-based legacy database system with AI is like trying to add full self-driving to a car from the 1980s‚Äîit‚Äôs not built for it.

Even if legacy platforms introduce AI-powered features, they‚Äôll be bolted on, not deeply integrated into the core system.

AI-native systems, on the other hand:
 Automate decision-making at the system level‚Äîno reliance on manual workflows.
 Use vector databases for real-time, similarity-based search, while legacy systems rely on exact-match lookups that don‚Äôt allow for true personalization.
 Have self-learning AI-driven sales and retention workflows, while legacy AI will be static and rule-based.

This isn‚Äôt just an evolution‚Äîit‚Äôs a fundamental shift in how software is designed and how businesses operate.

It‚Äôs not a matter of if, but when customers demand an AI-first system built from the ground up‚Äîand when that happens, legacy players will be scrambling to catch up.

postsData.content:
I was on a B2B website recently.

I was interested in learning more about their solution and further exploring their resources.

I was even willing to provide my name and email address to access the information.

One small problem though.

I couldn‚Äôt find the path to engage.

After a lot of scrolling and page views I eventually found a small call-to-action (CTA) hidden at the bottom of a page.

Buried deep in the bowels of their website I found where I could ‚ÄúSubscribe to Newsletter‚Äù.

It was a frustrating experience and I eventually ‚Äúbounced‚Äù off the website and went to one of their competitors.

We all want our clients to say we‚Äôre easy to do business with.

But being easy to do business with starts way before someone becomes a client.

It starts even before they become a lead.

It starts with how we present ourselves and engage with our market.

Being easy to do business with starts with being easy to engage online.

So offer your visitors clear paths to explore and take their ‚Äúnext-best-step‚Äù.

This means you can‚Äôt hide your CTAs.

PLACE YOUR CTA WHERE THE EYE CAN SEE.

Below are some of the best places :

 ABOVE THE FOLD

Place your primary CTA front and center in the most visible areas above the fold so it‚Äôs one of the first things visitors see.

 IN THE SIDEBAR

Sidebar CTAs stand out from the main content and are highly visible.

 EMBEDDED IN CONTENT

CTAs blended into and relevant to page content, like at the end of blog posts or embedded in videos, can work well.

 POP-UPS/OVERLAYS

While they can be annoying if overused, timed and targeted pop-up CTAs upon entering or exiting a page do garner attention.

 STICKY HEADER/FOOTER

CTAs in ‚Äústicky‚Äù elements that stay fixed onscreen as users scroll are visible the entire time.

 EXIT-INTENT

CTAs that appear when the mouse moves to leave the page tap into exit-intent and provide a last chance to convert.

 THANK YOU/CHECKOUT PAGES

Post-purchase and checkout pages have high conversions for natural next-step CTAs like reviews.

 HERO SECTIONS

Prominent CTAs often perform well when placed in visually engaging page header sections.

postsData.content:
Please DON‚ÄôT mind the gap!

Ever notice how, the moment we think we have a little gap, we want to fill it? We instinctively reach for our phones?

Standing in line? Scroll.
Waiting for a meeting? Check notifications.
Five minutes before your next task? Swipe, swipe, swipe.

And the worst? The non existent gap when someone is speaking with us!

It‚Äôs so automatic that we don‚Äôt even realize we‚Äôre doing it.

What if I were to say that those moments are precious. They‚Äôre opportunities, not gaps to fill mindlessly.

Break the Pattern of ‚ÄúFilling the Void‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what worked for me:

Pause Before Picking Up Your Phone
The next time you reach for your device, stop for just three breaths.

Ask yourself: Do I really need to check this right now? Often, the answer is no.

Anchor Yourself in the Present
Look around. What‚Äôs happening? Notice the sounds, the light, or the people. Observing your surroundings can be surprisingly grounding.

Redirect Your Energy
Use those moments to reflect or just be. Maybe you think about something you‚Äôre grateful for. Or simply let your mind wander, it‚Äôs amazing what clarity comes when you give your thoughts space.

As a rule - not looking mindlessly at the phone during a conversation and if I absolutely must, asking the other person‚Äôs permission to attend to something because it‚Äôs urgent.

Breaking the habit of mindless scrolling doesn‚Äôt happen overnight, but it starts with small, intentional choices.

Imagine reclaiming those moments, not as gaps to fill, but as opportunities to reconnect with yourself, people and the world around you.

Because some gaps are meant to be enjoyed.

postsData.content:
Asking Is Not Selling  Entrepreneur perspective. 

In the popular imagination, entrepreneurs are the consummate salespeople.

They are individuals with a compelling vision, equipped with the communication skills and forceful personalities that get others to ‚Äúbuy‚Äù into their ideas.

However, true entrepreneurship is not just about selling a vision, it‚Äôs about co-creating one. It‚Äôs about building relationships, fostering trust, and forming mutually beneficial partnerships that drive long-term success.

Robert Cialdini, in his book Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion, explores the science behind persuasion and the subtle yet powerful ways in which people are influenced. He identifies six key principles that shape human behavior:
 Social Proof ‚Äì People follow the actions of others, assuming that widespread behavior is the correct one.
 Authority ‚Äì Individuals are more likely to trust and obey those in positions of perceived expertise.
 Liking ‚Äì We are more easily persuaded by people we like and relate to.
 Scarcity ‚Äì The less available something seems, the more desirable it becomes.
 Reciprocation ‚Äì A favor given often compels a favor in return, creating a cycle of mutual exchange.
 Commitment & Consistency ‚Äì Once a person commits to something, they strive to act in ways that align with that commitment.

(good book/read btw - my recommendation)

These principles don‚Äôt just apply to sales, they define how we influence, lead, and collaborate. Whether you‚Äôre an entrepreneur, a leader, or a professional in any field, the key to long-term influence isn‚Äôt about convincing people to ‚Äúbuy‚Äù into your ideas. It‚Äôs about creating shared value, aligning goals, and fostering relationships that make persuasion feel natural rather than forced. Influence is not about manipulation, it‚Äôs about meaningful connection.




How do you use these principles in your work? Let‚Äôs discuss.

Retail businesses thrive on data-driven decision-making. I worked on a BigMart Sales Prediction Model, using XGBoost Regressor to forecast product sales across different outlets. This project highlights how machine learning can optimize inventory management, pricing, and marketing strategies.

The dataset contained multiple product and store-related features, including Item Weight, Item MRP, Outlet Size, Location Type, and Store Type. The challenge was to handle missing values, categorical encoding, and feature selection for accurate sales prediction.

Ô∏è Key Steps in the Project:
 Data Preprocessing: Filled missing values, standardized categories, and applied label encoding.
 Feature Engineering: Selected relevant features affecting sales.
 Model Implementation: Trained an XGBoost Regressor to predict sales.
 Evaluation: Achieved 87.59% R¬≤ on training data and 50.60% R¬≤ on test data.

 Results & Takeaways:
Ô∏è The model performed well on training data but showed signs of overfitting on test data.
Ô∏è Feature importance analysis can help optimize sales strategies.
Ô∏è Future improvements: Hyperparameter tuning, feature scaling, and testing other models like Random Forest and Linear Regression.

Retailers can leverage machine learning to optimize stock, adjust pricing, and improve customer satisfaction. This project highlights how data science can drive business growth.

Did OpenAI just burn $7 million on a Super Bowl ad, or was it marketing genius?

Over 120 million people watched the Super Bowl last night. But all anyone is talking about today? That cryptic OpenAI ad.

Is it a masterclass or a misfire?

Personally? I think it missed the mark. Here‚Äôs why:

 Most people watching have no clue what ChatGPT is.
 Even fewer know what the black circle means.

A Super Bowl ad is prime real estate for top-of-funnel awareness. You have millions of new eyeballs‚Äîpeople who might have never heard of you before‚Äîready to listen.

So why go cryptic?

Most brands go big with:
 Celeb cameos
 Humor
 A clear, memorable message

Something that makes you remember them and brings up conversations at work the next day.

Instead, OpenAI‚Äôs ad left most people saying:
 ‚ÄúWhat was that dot thing about?‚Äù

AI is still a niche bubble‚Äîthis ad didn‚Äôt break through. It just left people scratching their heads.

What do you think? Marketing win or wasted millions? ‚¨áÔ∏è

‚ÄúWe must not mistake kindness for weakness. Kindness isn‚Äôt weak. Kindness is a certain type of strength.‚Äù

~Jim Rohn ~

When we display kindness, it often comes from a place of compassion and strength, not a lack of it.

Unfortunately, there‚Äôs a persistent misconception that equates these acts of generosity and concern for others with weakness. This misunderstanding may stem from a variety of societal and psychological factors, and it‚Äôs important to recognize why this view is not only erroneous but also harmful.

Kindness is indeed a form of strength that requires resilience and a strong sense of self-worth to give of oneself without expecting anything in return.

By continuing to be kind, even in the face of skepticism, you embody the real essence of strength, which often goes beyond mere physical or assertive powers.

Kindness is STRENGTH‚Ä¶ Courtesy is POWER‚Ä¶
